case.name: AI-Assisted Medical Diagnosis System
case.description: Assurance case demonstrating that an AI system for assisting radiologists in detecting lung abnormalities operates safely and effectively within clinical settings.

tree.name: G1
tree.description: The AI-assisted diagnosis system is acceptably safe and effective for clinical deployment in lung abnormality detection.
tree.assumption: The system is used as a decision-support tool, with final diagnosis made by qualified radiologists.
tree.justification: Patient safety and diagnostic accuracy are paramount in healthcare AI systems, requiring comprehensive assurance.

comments.author: clinical_lead
comments.content: This case aligns with MHRA guidance on AI as a Medical Device.

children.name: S1
children.description: Argue safety and effectiveness through decomposition into performance validation, risk management, and human factors assurance.
children.justification: This decomposition follows the structure recommended by FDA guidance on Clinical Decision Support Software.

children.name: P1
children.description: System sensitivity for detecting clinically significant lung nodules exceeds 95% threshold.
children.assumption: Clinically significant defined as nodules â‰¥6mm requiring follow-up per Fleischner Society guidelines.
children.justification: 95% sensitivity threshold established through clinical stakeholder consultation and literature review.

children.name: E1
children.description: Clinical validation study report showing 97.2% sensitivity (95% CI: 95.1-98.6%) on 2,847 patient cohort.

children.name: P2
children.description: System specificity maintains acceptable false positive rate to avoid unnecessary patient anxiety and follow-up procedures.

children.name: P2.1
children.description: False positive rate per scan is below 1.5, meeting clinical acceptability threshold.
children.justification: Threshold based on published radiologist performance benchmarks and clinical workflow impact analysis.

children.name: E2
children.description: Validation study results: 0.8 false positives per scan (SD: 0.3), significantly below threshold.

children.name: P3
children.description: Performance is consistent across demographic subgroups without clinically significant disparities.
children.assumption: Subgroups defined by age, sex, and ethnicity as recorded in clinical datasets.

children.name: E3
children.description: Subgroup analysis report showing no statistically significant performance differences (p>0.05) across demographic groups.

comments.author: data_scientist
comments.content: Age stratification shows slight decrease in 80+ cohort - flagged for monitoring.

children.name: S2
children.description: Identify hazards through FMEA, assess risks, and demonstrate mitigation effectiveness.
children.justification: FMEA is the standard technique for medical device risk analysis per ISO 14971.

children.name: P4
children.description: All reasonably foreseeable hazards have been systematically identified and documented.

children.name: E4
children.description: FMEA report documenting 47 identified hazards across software, integration, and use-related categories.

children.name: P5
children.description: All high and medium severity risks have been mitigated to acceptable residual risk levels.
children.assumption: Risk acceptability matrix approved by clinical safety officer.

children.name: P5.1
children.description: Risk of false negative (missed abnormality) is mitigated through mandatory radiologist review of all AI-negative cases.
children.justification: Human-in-the-loop design ensures AI augments rather than replaces clinical judgement.

children.name: E5
children.description: Clinical workflow specification mandating radiologist sign-off on all cases, with audit trail logging.

children.name: P5.2
children.description: Risk of automation bias (over-reliance on AI) is mitigated through training and interface design.

children.name: E6
children.description: Mandatory training programme including automation bias awareness module, with 100% radiologist completion.

children.name: E7
children.description: User interface design document showing confidence calibration display and uncertainty communication.

children.name: S3
children.description: Demonstrate usability through formative and summative human factors evaluation.

children.name: P6
children.description: System usability has been validated with representative end users in simulated clinical environment.

children.name: E8
children.description: Summative usability study report: 15 radiologists completed 10 representative tasks with 100% success rate, SUS score 82.5.

children.name: P7
children.description: System integrates seamlessly with existing clinical workflow without increasing radiologist workload.
children.justification: Workflow efficiency is critical for clinical adoption and sustained safe use.

children.name: E9
children.description: Time-motion study showing 12% reduction in average case review time with AI assistance.
